Getting Started¶

PyFair is an open-source implementation of the Factor Analysis of Information Risk (FAIR) methodology.

Main API Classes¶

FairModel¶

class pyfair.model.model.FairModel(name, n_simulations=10000, random_seed=42, model_uuid=None, creation_date=None)¶

A main class to act as an API for FAIR Model construction.

A single instance of this class is created for each FAIR model. It contains a dependency resolution tree (self._tree), a calculation member (self._calculation), and an input parser (self._input).

Calculations are strucutred as a series of connected nodes, with one node for each of the potential FAIR inputs. A user interacts with this class by loading data via JSON or by inputting data for the individual nodes. The user then triggers the calculate_all() method to run all the subcalculations necessary to complete the FAIR model.

Parameters:
  • name (str) – A human-readable designation for identification
  • n_simulations (int, optional) – Number of simulations created (default is 10,000)
  • random_seed (int, optional) – Random seed for number generation (default is 42)
  • model_uuid (str, optional) – uuid.uuid4 string (default is None, meaning one will be assigned)
  • creation_date (str, optional) –

    Creation date (default is None, meaning one will be assigned)

    Warning

    Do not supply your own UUID/creation date unless you want to break things.
bulk_import_data(param_dictionary)¶

Import via nested dict and self._input/self._tree

calculate_all()¶

Calculate nodes and update depedency tree with self._calculation

calculation_completed()¶

Returns True if calculation is complete via self._tree

Return model name

get_node_statuses()¶

Return the statuses of each node from captive self._tree

Input nested dict for multidimensional inputs (Secondary Loss)

Static method to instatiate model from JSON

to_json()¶

Export model as JSON

bulk_import_data(param_dictionary)

Takes multiple inputs via nested dictionaries.

The function iterates through a dictionary and runs input_data() for each item. This allows for multiple items to be added at a single time. The param dictionary will take the form:

{‘target_1’: {param_1: value_1}, ‘target_2’: {param_2: value_2}}

Parameters:param_dictionary (dict) – A nested dictionary of parameters.
Returns:A reference to this object of type FairModel
Return type:pyfair.model.FairModel

Examples

>>> model = pyfair.FairModel(name="Insider Threat")
>>> model.bulk_import_data({
...     'Loss Event Frequency': {'mean': 90, 'stdev': 100},
...     'Loss Magnitude': {'constant': 4000},
... })
calculate_all()

Runs all outstanding calculations for uncalculated nodes.

This is done by obtaining a list of all ‘calculatble’ nodes. If it is not ready for a complete calculation, it throws an error. It goes through all the calculable nodes and calculates them using the private _calculate_node() method.

Raises:pyfair.fair_exception.FairException – Raised is complete calculation is impossible.
Returns:A reference to this object of type FairModel
Return type:pyfair.model.FairModel

Examples

>>> model = pyfair.FairModel(name="Insider Threat")
>>> model.bulk_import_data({
...     'Loss Event Frequency': {'mean': 90, 'stdev': 100},
...     'Loss Magnitude': {'constant': 4000},
... })
... model.calculate_all)()
calculation_completed()

Public method to check completion status of dependency tree

Returns:Whether the calculation dependencies are satisfied
Return type:bool
export_params()

Export params as a dictioanry.

Returns:Non-metadata parameters
Return type:dict
export_results()

Exports the result of the calculation as a dataframe

Returns:A reference to this object of type FairModel
Return type:pandas.DataFrame

Examples

>>> model = pyfair.FairModel(name="Insider Threat")
>>> model.bulk_import_data({
...     'Loss Event Frequency': {'mean': 90, 'stdev': 100},
...     'Loss Magnitude': {'constant': 4000},
... })
... model.calculate_all)()
... results = model.export_results()
get_name()

Gives the name of the model

Returns:Name of model
Return type:str
get_node_statuses()

Public method access private node status information in ._tree

Returns:A series with index of nodes, and values of statuses
Return type:pandas.Series
input_data(target, **kwargs)

Input data for a single node

This takes input, feeds it to self._data_input.generate(), and updates the dependencies via self._tree.update_status(). The kwargs can be for normal (keywords mean and stdev), BetaPert (keywords low, mode, high, and gamma), Bernoulli/binomial (keywords p), or a constant (keywords constant).

Parameters:
  • target (str) – The name of the node for which the arguments are directed
  • kwargs (dict) – The arguments used to generate a distribution for the node
Returns:

A reference to this object of type FairModel
Return type:

pyfair.model.FairModel

Examples

>>> model = pyfair.model.FairModel(name='Data Loss')
>>> model.input_data('Loss Magnitude', {'mean': 20, 'stdev': 10})
input_multi_data(target, kwargs_dict)

Input data for multiple items that roll up into an aggrgate

As of now, this is only used for Secondary Loss when calculating mutliple secondary loss line items (e.g. ‘Reputation’ has a probability of A and a loss of B; ‘Morale’ has a probability of C and a loss of D, etc.).

Parameters:
  • target (str) – The name of the node for which the arguments are directed
  • kwargs_dict (dict) – The arguments used to generate a distribution for the node
Returns:

A reference to this object of type FairModel
Return type:

pyfair.model.FairModel

Examples

>>> model = pyfair.FairModel(name="Insider Threat")
>>> model1.input_multi_data('Secondary Loss', {
...     'Reputational': {
...         'Secondary Loss Event Frequency': {'constant': 4000},
...         'Secondary Loss Event Magnitude': {'low': 10, 'mode': 20, 'high': 100},
...     },
...     'Legal': {
...         'Secondary Loss Event Frequency': {'constant': 2000},
...         'Secondary Loss Event Magnitude': {'low': 10, 'mode': 20, 'high': 100},
...     }
... })
static read_json(param_json)

Static method to create a model from a JSON string

Parameters:param_json (str) – a UTF-8 encoded JSON string containing model data
Returns:A model instance using the JSON parameters supplied
Return type:pyfair.model.FairModel
Raises:pyfair.fair_exception.FairException – If metamodel JSON is supplied erroneously

Example

>>> with open('serialized_model.json') as f:
...     json_text = f.read()
...
>>> model = FairModel.read_json(json_text)
to_json()

Dump the model as JSON string

For an example, see the file: “serialized_model.json”.

Returns:A JSON string representing the model information.
Return type:str

Examples

>>> model = pyfair.FairModel(name="Insider Threat")
>>> model.bulk_import_data({
...     'Loss Event Frequency': {'mean': 90, 'stdev': 100},
...     'Loss Magnitude': {'constant': 4000},
... })
... model.calculate_all)()
... json_data = model.to_json()

FairBetaPert¶

class pyfair.utility.beta_pert.FairBetaPert(low, mode, high, gamma=4)¶

A PERT distribution for all your pseudoscientific needs.

Formula taken from:
https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/prevalence/versions/0.4.0/topics/betaPERT http://mech.vub.ac.be/teaching/info/Ontwerpmethodologie/Appendix%20les%202%20PERT.pdf
